qas.question: Ciliary rosettes pump water into what to control buoyancy?
What does pumping water into the mesoglea do?

answers.text: increase its bulk and decrease its density
increase its bulk and decrease its density
increase its bulk and decrease its density

qas.question: What does the ciliary rosettes do to decease bulk and increase density?

answers.text: pump water out of the mesoglea
pump water out of the mesoglea

qas.question: How do mesoglea control how brackish body fluids are?
What do mesoglea adapt to when relying on brackish water?
What is volume normally as concentrated as?
What does pumping in regular seawater do to  its bulk?
Why do do ciliary rosettes need to decrease density in seawater?

context: It is uncertain how ctenophores control their buoyancy, but experiments have shown that some species rely on osmotic pressure to adapt to water of different densities. Their body fluids are normally as concentrated as seawater. If they enter less dense brackish water, the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density, to avoid sinking. Conversely if they move from brackish to full-strength seawater, the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume and increase its density.
